channel.title: How To Make A Static IP Address
channel.description:
So, when you portforward, you enter your ip address into your router and the port you want it on. But an IP address can change, and then it try's to portforward your old address, but that address is non-existent.
This tutorial is for XP users. Probably will be the same with Vista and 7.
First, hit Start and open the Control Panel.
Then find Network Connections [img]http://www.bwenhost.webs.com/1.bmp[/img]
Right click on whatever your connection is (like Local Area Connection 2), and hit Properties.
Then select Internet Protocol TCP/IP, and hit Properties [img]http://www.bwenhost.webs.com/2.bmp[/img]
Minimize that window. Click start and hit Run. Type cmd. Type in ipconfig/all
Find your connection.
It should look like this [img]http://www.bwenhost.webs.com/3.bmp[/img]
Find (IP Address) It will be 192.168.0. (something) Find Default Gateway Find DHCP Server Find DNS Servers Find Subnet Mask
Remember those. There all 192.168.0.1 for me. For most, its 192.168.1.1
Open back up the Protocol TCP/IP. It should say Obtain IP Address automatically. Select Use The Following IP Address.
Type the IP Address you want to use Example: Mine is 192.168.0.60 Your subnet mask should be 255.255.255.0 by default. I think it will even put the subnet mask in for you. Enter your default gateway. Mine is 192.168.0.1 Yours will probably be 192.168.1.1 or something...
Find Preferred DNS Server. Enter yours. It should be the same as your default gateway. Leave alternate blank.
You can repair or disable and re-enable your connection to make sure it worked. Then go to cmd and type ipconfig to check.
Your done!!!!!!!

That’s for the IPv4 addresses.

They are selling them due to the shortage, which is one reason why IPv6 was created.

Read full topic
item.source: How To Make A Static IP Address

item.title: How To Make A Static IP Address
item.dc:creator: @chaos_666 chaos 666
item.description:
@chaos_666 wrote:

[quote=“EmulousGuru, post:10, topic:364108”][quote author=chaos 666 link=topic=460341.msg3369526#msg3369526 date=1287103173]

[quote author=EmulousGuru link=topic=460341.msg3369524#msg3369524 date=1287103123]

If the provider wants to they can give your static IP to someone else when your router is turned off.
[/quote]That made absolutely no sense…

It does really, that’s how it all works. IP adresses are getting rarer each day, there are even black markets in several countries that sell IP adresses. If the provider would be in need they could take any of their IPs that isn’t being used and all they’d have to do is get you another one when you get back on.

Also if it made no sense they wouldn’t have had to develop IPv6 to succeed IPv4.
[/quote]They made IPv6 due to the Internet boom, which was expected to run out of the ‘address pool’ in approximately 2011-2012.

As IPv4 uses 32 bits, and can hold up to 232 addresses, whereas IPv6 is 128 bits, and can hold up to 2128 addresses. IPv6 was also developed for faster processing, as it has a fixed header length of only 40 bytes.

As for the ‘selling’ of IP-addresses, I have no clue what you mean, because most people have common IPv4 / IPv6 addresses.

Such as many people use 192.168.1.1 (Or a static range of digits, based on the 192.168..)
That doesn’t mean nobody else can have that same number. (Unless, they are on the same network connection, then of course, they can’t be given the same static range.)[/quote]

You looked up the difference between IPv4 abd IPv6 and gave me information that I already had to learn for my previous exams. If you really want to know more about the selling of IP addresses you could also just google it. “ip address black market” gives enough hits on google to explain it to you.

EDIT: here’s the google link: http://www.google.be/search?q=ip+adress+black+market&ie=utf-8&oe=utf-8&aq=t&rls=org.mozilla:nl:official&client=firefox-a#hl=nl&client=firefox-a&hs=RUZ&rls=org.mozilla:nl:official&&sa=X&ei=G6m3TPnWNMabOszqpLMJ&ved=0CBUQvwUoAQ&q=ip+address+black+market&spell=1&fp=d23bdf02be6a8984

Read full topic
item.source: How To Make A Static IP Address

item.title: How To Make A Static IP Address
item.dc:creator: @EmulousGuru EmulousGuru
item.description:
@EmulousGuru wrote:

[quote=“chaos 666, post:9, topic:364108”][quote author=EmulousGuru link=topic=460341.msg3369524#msg3369524 date=1287103123]

If the provider wants to they can give your static IP to someone else when your router is turned off.
[/quote]That made absolutely no sense…

It does really, that’s how it all works. IP adresses are getting rarer each day, there are even black markets in several countries that sell IP adresses. If the provider would be in need they could take any of their IPs that isn’t being used and all they’d have to do is get you another one when you get back on.

Also if it made no sense they wouldn’t have had to develop IPv6 to succeed IPv4.[/quote]They made IPv6 due to the Internet boom, which was expected to run out of the ‘address pool’ in approximately 2011-2012.

As IPv4 uses 32 bits, and can hold up to 232 addresses, whereas IPv6 is 128 bits, and can hold up to 2128 addresses. IPv6 was also developed for faster processing, as it has a fixed header length of only 40 bytes.

As for the ‘selling’ of IP-addresses, I have no clue what you mean, because most people have common IPv4 / IPv6 addresses.

Such as many people use 192.168.1.1 (Or a static range of digits, based on the 192.168..)
That doesn’t mean nobody else can have that same number. (Unless, they are on the same network connection, then of course, they can’t be given the same static range.)

Read full topic

item.title: How To Make A Static IP Address
item.dc:creator: @benny679 benny679
item.description:
@benny679 wrote:

So, when you portforward, you enter your ip address into your router and the port you want it on. But an IP address can change, and then it try’s to portforward your old address, but that address is non-existent.

This tutorial is for XP users. Probably will be the same with Vista and 7.

First, hit Start and open the Control Panel.

Then find Network Connections

Right click on whatever your connection is (like Local Area Connection 2), and hit Properties.

Then select Internet Protocol TCP/IP, and hit Properties

Minimize that window.
Click start and hit Run.
Type cmd.
Type in ipconfig/all

Find your connection.

It should look like this

Find (IP Address) It will be 192.168.0. (something)
Find Default Gateway
Find DHCP Server
Find DNS Servers
Find Subnet Mask

Remember those. There all 192.168.0.1 for me. For most, its 192.168.1.1

Open back up the Protocol TCP/IP. It should say Obtain IP Address automatically. Select Use The Following IP Address.

Type the IP Address you want to use Example: Mine is 192.168.0.60
Your subnet mask should be 255.255.255.0 by default. I think it will even put the subnet mask in for you.
Enter your default gateway. Mine is 192.168.0.1 Yours will probably be 192.168.1.1 or something…

Find Preferred DNS Server. Enter yours. It should be the same as your default gateway.
Leave alternate blank.

You can repair or disable and re-enable your connection to make sure it worked. Then go to cmd and type ipconfig to check.

Your done!!!
